To the editor,

Re: Outdoor rec enthusiasts petition for range access, May 21.

In your recent article, the lieutenant-commander offers a curiously anachronistic defence of the military's right to continue to fire live ammunition miles into a forest area adjacent to a popular public park.

When the range was established almost a century ago it was in an extremely remote location, but the world has changed and it now presents a risk to public safety.

Apart from the risk of hitting people and wildlife, the spent ammunition produces undetermined toxic waste close to a public water source. Furthermore during our hot, dry summers there must be a significant risk of starting a forest fire. At critical times the use of power tools and lawn mowers is banned, how about gun ranges?

It is clear that major changes in attitude are required by the federal government. If this range is not relocated to a new 'safe' location, if such a place exists, then the operators should create barriers to prevent stray ammunition flying miles into to the forest.

Carl Jones, Nanaimo

urn:contentItem:5XTC-1301-JBTY-W0P0-00000-00Canadians help fight Australian wildfires2019-12-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A2Canadians help fight Australian wildfiresHighly trained staff from several agencies embark on weekslong deploymentThe Canadian Press

Sixty-nine Canadians are giving up their holidays at home to join the battle for the first time against the deadly wildfires devastating vast tracts of several Australian states.

The Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre says a contingent of 21 highly trained staff from a variety of agencies left Canada on Dec. 3 for a 38-day deployment in New South Wales after the centre received an official request for assistance.

On Dec. 19, a second group of 30 Canadians was sent in for a 38-day deployment in the fire zone, and a further 18 are leaving on Dec. 30 for about a month.

Kim Connors, the executive director of the Winnipeg-based CIFFC, says that Canada has called on Australian firefighters four times since 2015, and the "agreements are reciprocal in nature, so it was the first time that Australia has needed help from Canada."

"Our Canadian firefighters and their families have volunteered their time to be away for the holidays, which is different for the northern hemisphere to be dealing with wildland fires over Christmas and New Year's," Connors said.

"So we're very proud of them for doing that," he said in an interview."

The CIFFC says crews from Newfoundland and Labrador, Quebec, Yukon, Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and B.C. are assisting with a variety of tasks, including roles in command, aviation, planning, logistics and operations.

"So they're not on the front line, they're in the overall management of the fires," said Connors.

"They've been in a period of drought for quite a long period, and it's not a very good situation down there and obviously their summer is just started, as our winter starts."

Record high temperatures and strong southerly winds are fanning more than 100 fires in New South Wales alone.

Two volunteer firefighters have been killed and dozens of homes have been lost since Thursday in the massive fires, including the Gospers Mountain blaze, which covered more than 460,000 hectares.

(CP) _ About 800 evacuees from one of the southwest Alberta communities threatened by a massive forest fire were told Wednesday they will be allowed to return to their homes.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Officials decided the threat to Hillcrest from the rampaging Lost Creek forest fire had diminished.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"We felt it was safe enough for them to return,'' said municipal Coun. Jerry Rejman.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>About 100 firefighters remained in the area with hoses, sprinkling systems and heavy equipment.</p><p>"We're telling people to be very careful,'' Rejman said. "There's still some mopping-up operations.''</p><p>Hillcrest was evacuated on Saturday when flames burned to within 500 metres of the community. Crowsnest Pass Mayor John Irwin said some hot spots remained, but all that was left in the area between the blaze and town had already burned, so there was no timber left for the fire to consume.</p><p>The ruling affected almost half the people that were driven from their homes by the persistent blaze, which fire officials said had grown to 190 square kilometres. About 1,000 people remained evacuated from Blairmore, another community in Crowsnest Pass.</p><p>Changes in the fire's behaviour, meanwhile, allowed crews to attack the main body of the fire instead of being limited to the rear and the flanks.</p><p>"When the fire is up in the trees and rolling, it's very difficult to get in front of it,'' said fire information officer Patrick Loewen. "What it's done in the last few days has allowed us to get right at the head of the fire and concentrate our efforts there with 'dozer lines and backburning and other techniques to rob it of fuel.''</p><p>Although the fire remained out of control, about 850 firefighters and support workers backed up by eight air tankers were able to keep it from growing.</p><p>Crews have been getting some help from a sprinkling of rain and higher humidity, said Loewen. Similar conditions were expected over the next few days.</p><p>"We're getting a little bit of help from Mother Nature.''</p><p>The news from British Columbia was not as encouraging, as one official said Wednesday it may be weeks before evacuees can return home.</p><p>The largest of three B.C. fires grew by 30 per cent Wednesday, driven by winds gusting up to 80 kilometres an hour.</p><p>The Hillcrest evacuees, which included some residents who were sent packing from their neighbourhood July 27, were allowed to go home through one controlled access point.</p><p>"People are very happy,'' said Rejman, who added the fire had not damaged the town.</p><p>Alberta's sustainable resource development minister said Wednesday people who start fires will be made to pay the costs.</p><p>"We do have a policy that we will initiate the cost recovery on any fire where we can identify a responsible party. . . If they refuse to pay, then we will initiate legal action,'' Mike Cardinal said.</p><p>"I think we have to, not only to recover the cost of the damage for the taxpayer, but to deter people from starting fires or being careless.''</p><p>But he acknowledged it is often difficult, if not impossible, to identify a culprit.</p><p>Over the past five years, an average of 20 people per year were billed for the costs of fighting forest fires, said department spokesman Terry Cunha. "We bill them, on average, half a million dollars.''</p><p>Further north in Jasper National Park, Parks Canada officials estimated the Syncline fire in the park's southeast section was holding at 250 square kilometres.</p><p>"It hasn't actually grown that much in the past day,'' said Parks Canada spokeswoman Geri Syroteuk.</p><p>Southwest winds were expected to push the blaze further into the Jasper backcountry, although it wasn't threatening any park infrastructure or tourist facilities.</p><p>A second fire in the Maligne Lake area was limited to 14 hectares and was being held, Syroteuk said. The road into the popular destination was reopened along with tourist facilities _ although boating was not being allowed on the east side of the lake to allow helicopters to continue to fill water buckets.</p><p>At least one of Kootenay National Park's two major fires was growing. The Verendrye Creek fire doubled in size since Tuesday to 30 square kilometres while the Tokumm Creek blaze was at 4.5 square kilometres.</p><p>Heavy smoke from those fires hung over the valleys in the area and contributed to the continued closure of Hwy 93 south of the Trans-Canada Highway.</p><p>"Typically it's worst in the early morning hours,'' said Ian Pengelly of Parks Canada.</p><p>"This season would be comparable to 1936, which would be one of the most severe fire seasons of the last century.''</p><p>Near Hunter Valley in central Alberta, firefighters were making headway against two small fires, although not before sizeable losses at a local forestry company.</p><p>"We're certainly talking hundreds of thousands of dollars here,'' said Tom Daniels of Sunpine Forest Products urn:contentItem:5XTC-J2F1-JBVR-327N-00000-00Sixty-nine Canadians giving up holidays to help with Australian wildfires2019-12-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisNATIONALSixty-nine Canadians giving up holidays to help with Australian wildfiresMore Canadians to help with Australia firesThe Canadian Press

TORONTO - Sixty-nine Canadians are giving up their holidays at home to join the battle for the first time against the deadly wildfires devastating vast tracts of several Australian states.

The Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre says a contingent of 21 highly trained staff from a variety of agencies left Canada on Dec. 3, for a 38 day deployment in New South Wales after the centre received an official request for assistance.

On Dec. 19 a second group of 30 Canadians was sent in for a 38 day deployment in the fire zone, anda further 18 are leaving on Dec. 30 for about a month.

Kim Connors, the executive director of the Winnipeg based CIFFC, says that Canada has called on Australian firefighters four times since 2015, and the "agreements are reciprocal in nature so it was the first time that Australia has needed help from Canada."

"Our Canadian firefighters and their families have volunteered their time to be away for the holidays, which is different for the northern hemisphere to be dealing with wildland fires over Christmas and New Year's so we're very proud of them for doing that," he said in an interview.

The CIFFC says crews from Newfoundland and Labrador, Quebec, Yukon, Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and B.C. are assisting with a variety of tasks including roles in command, aviation, planning, logistics and operations.

"So they're not on the front line, they're in the overall management of the fires," said Connors.

"They've been in a period of drought for quite a long period and it's not a very good situation down there and obviously their summer is just started as our winter starts."

Record high temperatures and strong southerly winds are fanning more than 100 fires in New South Wales alone.

Two volunteer firefighters have been killed and dozens of homes have been lost since Thursday in the massive fires, including the Gospers Mountain blaze, which covered more than 460,000 hectares.

This report by The Canadian Press was first published Dec. 22, 2019

- quick access to provincial and territorial fire agencies; and

You can also use the near-real-time interactive map to zoom in on forest fires near your community, or you can view periodic satellite images of larger active fires.

Forest fires affect millions of hectares of forest each year. Although they are an important part of nature's cycle of renewal, they can also threaten the lives and livelihoods of Canadians.

SANDIE RINALDO: Parts of Australia are dealing with catastrophic wildfires fueled by extreme heat, strong winds, and drought. At least nine people are dead, one body discovered today. Thousands of firefighters are desperately trying to contain the spreading flames, including 52 Canadians who will spend Christmas on the frontlines. CTV's Melanie Nagy has our report.

MELANIE NAGY (Reporter): Raging and relentless wildfires voraciously consuming everything in their path. More than a hundred continue to burn across some of Australia's most populous states. With so many erratic wildfires, officials are asking people to avoid holiday travel. They fear drivers could get stuck on roads near fire zones. For weeks now, Australia has been gripped by a wildfire crisis. Hundreds of homes and businesses have been destroyed.

MARK WAILEY: Just a huge wall of flames just came. I had to hide behind the corner as it was coming.

NAGY: Several people have also died, including two volunteer firefighters. While Australia is hit by wildfires every year, the intense season started early. The record-breaking heat is making things worse. In some areas, temperatures neared 50 degrees. This week, protestors shut down streets in Sydney, and called on the government to declare a climate emergency. The country's prime minister cut short a trip to Hawaii after being criticized for vacationing during the crisis.

SCOTT MORRISON (Australian Prime Minister): I get it that people would have been upset to know that I was holidaying with my family while their families were under great stress.

NAGY: There are more than 2,000 firefighters battling the wildfires. To help, Canada has sent in teams specializing in aviation, logistics, and fire behaviour.

KIM CONNORS (Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre): Australia has been in Canada four times now since 2015, and, but this is the first time that they've asked for this kind of help from so far away.

NAGY: The Canadian teams are stationed in command centres. But if Australia asks for more firefighters, officials here say they'll send in additional crews. Sandie.

RINALDO: Mel, thank you.

The act also says parties may be ordered to reimburse the government for firefighting costs. The province said it spent more than $30 million fighting the blaze.</p><p>The government is still investigating the fire, but it had no choice but to lay charges at this time, said Bart Johnson, spokesman for Alberta Justice.</p><p>Under the Forest Prairie and Protection Act, the province had six months from when the fire started to take legal action. The fire started May 23 and time was about to run out. No court date has been set.</p><p>CN declined to meet with a committee that was evaluating how various agencies fought the fire. The independent committee previously concluded the fire began near a CN railway line.</p><p>Graham Dallas, a Vancouver spokesman for CN Railway, told Global News on Monday that the company conducted its own fact-finding mission after the blaze and found no evidence to suggest it was responsible.</p><p> We do everything we possibly can to make sure our rail operations are safe both for our employees and the communities we operate through,'' Dallas said.</p><p>Forestry and transportation officials said in May that trains can start fires if sparks from the engine or brakes ignite dry vegetation along the track. In its investigation, the government committee said the proximity of the rail lines to the place where the fire started raised some questions.</p><p>Residents had complained firefighters didn't do enough to save their homes from a fire, but a government report earlier this month concluded policies were followed and nothing else could have been done.</p><p>Mary and Ron Giselbrecht, who lost their home in the fire, said they considered hiring a lawyer but doubted they would garner any kind of profit by suing CN or RaiLink if either company were found guilty.</p><p> It's not going to help us at all,'' Mary Giselbrecht said.</p><p> They ain't gonna worry about us. We're just peasants.''</p><p>After the release of the report, Mike Cardinal, minister for sustainable resource development, said his department would change the way it operates to improve its ability to fight forest fires in the future.</p><p>The steps include better communication between government agencies, better planning and more work on suppressing hazards to prevent forest fires.</p><p>Resources used to battle the blaze that destroyed about 1,160 square kilometres of forested land included 514 firefighters, 34 helicopters, 31 bulldozers, 201 skidders, 45 water trucks and 84 fire-management personnel.</p><p>Chisholm is about 150 kilometres north of Edmonton.</p><p>(Edmonton Journal-Edmonton Sun)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Many spent the night with friends, relatives or at a shelter set up at a local school.</p><p>Helicopters were in the air looking for hot spots, but officials believe the worst of the threat is over.</p><p>Police say the fire was the result of human error. It is not known if there will be criminal charges.</p><p>"It wasn't a naturally caused fire,'' said Const. Bruce Brophy, of Tantalon RCMP.</p><p>"I'm not sure if there are charges if they will be municipal charges or criminal charges.''</p><p>There is no damage estimate available, but no homes were damaged. A firefighter received scrapes and cuts and one resident who has asthma had to be taken out by ambulance.</p><p>Constantly shifting winds throughout the night forced continual reassessment of the situation.</p><p>Shifting winds late Wednesday prevented dozens of firefighters and four water-dropping helicopters from containing the blaze, which had turned late in the day toward another subdivision in the heavily forested area.</p><p>Large plumes of smoke hung over the area about 20 minutes outside Halifax as officials went door-to-door to evacuate homes.</p><p>The fire burned to within 60 metres of some homes shortly after the fire began in the afternoon. One resident who had been asked to leave his home said flames were shooting up to 10 metres in the air.</p><p>More than 100 RCMP and police officers manned barricades, directing traffic or helping in the evacuation effort.</p><p>Salvation Army volunteers carted food and drink to weary firefighters.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata They pushed it along towards the community.''</p><p>In Alberta, a wildfire forced 180 people to flee the aboriginal hamlet of Sandy Lake, about 300 kilometres north of Edmonton.</p><p> The conditions are terrible here for fires,'' said David Zabot, deputy reeve of the Municipal District of Opportunity.</p><p>Temperatures reached 30 C and 35 km/h winds pushed the fire to within one kilometre of the hamlet.</p><p> They had no time at all to get ready. They left as fast as they could,'' Zabot said. Residents just grabbed their families and got the heck out of town. Most of them left with only the clothes on their back.</p><p> People didn't believe there was a fire at first because the smoke dissipated with the strong winds. It was hard to believe.''</p><p>Zabot said the fire was started by a lightning storm which went through the area Monday night.</p><p>Most people are staying at a hotel and community hall in nearby Wabasca.</p><p> With any luck, they will be back in their homes (Wednesday),'' Zabot said. We erred on the side of caution.''</p><p>Zabot estimated at least nine water bombers, three helicopters, as well as other heavy equipment, would be working through the night to contain the fire.</p><p>At Turnor Lake and Birch Narrows, the evacuations began Monday afternoon as children, the elderly, and those with respiratory problems such as asthma were taken to nearby Buffalo Narrows, La Loche and Meadow Lake.</p><p>The rest of the people in the communities were evacuated Tuesday morning.</p><p>Many were staying at the Meadow Lake Alliance Church, about a three and a half hour drive to the south, where they will sleep in a gymnasium on beds trucked in from North Battleford, Sask., said Suzanne Jost, church secretary.</p><p>She said the evacuees could end up staying at the church for several days, given the current conditions.</p><p> Just when you think the fire is out, it is not _ and the weather is so hot,'' she said.</p><p>Greyeyes said the fire has already consumed more than 200 square kilometres of timber.</p><p>RCMP Const. Kim Gobeil said late Tuesday that the fire had come very close to the communities, burning a few sheds, but no homes had been lost.</p><p> Everything in town is OK for now,'' he said. It's a little more under control.''</p><p>He said at one point firefighters had to retreat by boat because the smoke was so thick. However, no one had been injured.</p><p>Water bombers and fire crews were working to try and contain the blaze.</p><p>Saskatchewan Environment has also set up industrial sprinkler systems on buildings and in trees to shower the village with water.</p><p>As of Tuesday, there were 59 forest fires burning in the province.</p><p>Meanwhile, in Alberta, fire officials have announced plans to enact a fire ban over most of the northern and central parts of the province Wednesday. The ban will include the use of fireworks, firecrackers and sparklers.</p><p>There were 57 fires burning in Saskatchewan on Tuesday, including 29 which were burning out of control. There were 30 new fires in the past 24 hours.</p><p>(Saskatoon StarPhoenix-Edmonton Journal)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5W5J-7K71-F103-3465-00000-00B.C. sends 267 firefighters to help battle Alberta wildfires2019-05-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisNEWSB.C. sends 267 firefighters to help battle Alberta wildfires

More than 250 B.C. firefighters and staff are headed to Alberta to help with the out-of-control wildfires ravaging the province.

The province said 230 firefighters, a 19-person incident management team, 14 supervisors and three agency representatives are headed east on Wednesday and Thursday.

The request, which was made through the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, could leave the B.C. crews in Alberta for up to 19 days, although the province says there are enough in B.C. to keep fires here at home under control.

There are currently five out of control wildfires in Alberta, one of which started in the last 24 hours. So far to date, there have been 443, up from an annual average of 432 in the last five years.

A northern Alberta wildfire has seen 5,000 people cleared out of High Level and nearby First Nations, as flames lick at the southern edge of the community, located about 750 kilometres northwest of Edmonton.

Official reports said flames were within three kilometres of the town.

In B.C., there have been seven new fires started in the past week and 40 burning overall.

(CP)_ The fire danger rating in the Prince George region has been downgraded to moderate from high-to-extreme because of cooler temperatures and rain.</p><p nitf:lede="true">While the 18,000-hectare Tatuk Lake Fire, about 150 kilometres southwest of Prince George, only received a misting of rain, it did not grow, Fire Centre spokesperson Faye Hirshfield said Wednesday.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>There are still more than 150 firefighters battling that blaze, which is located south of Vanderhoof. That Tatuk Lake fire is one of three fires west and southwest of the Prince George that are the hotspots in the province. The Chinlak fire received some rain and remains under 300 hectares, where more than 50 fighters are stilling fighting the burn, located about 50 kilometres west of Prince George, near the junction of the Stuart and Nechako rivers.</p><p>The two fires are considered zero-per-cent contained. The Batnuni fire, south of Tatuk Lake, remains about 600 hectares. There are 60 firefighters working on that blaze. That fire is considered 95 per cent contained. All three fires were sparked by lightning strikes last weekend. Firefighters should get more relief this week with temperatures forecast to remain below 20 C through to Sunday.</p><p>(Prince George Citizen)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier A trio of government workers was going from property to property to contact individual miners, said Dennis Senger, spokesman for the Emergency Measures Organization.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>As of noon Monday, none of the 25 miners believed to be in the evacuation zone had checked in to social services numbers in Dawson City, said Senger.</p><p>Once the evacuation order was issued late Saturday night, the public advisory was distributed throughout town and calls to the affected area began.</p><p>A Northwestel transmitter that sends regular messages to the gold fields was used to radio the alert to placer miners, and satellite and radio phone calls were made to mining camps.</p><p>"There's smoke in the area; there's fires in the area,'' said Senger. "These people have been advised it's a serious situation out there. No one has come forward to sign in as requested.''</p><p>Authorities have set up a roadblock restricting access to the area. Yukon Energy on Sunday shut off the transmission line moving power from Mayo to Dawson, putting the town onto backup diesel generators as the fire came within 2.5 kilometres of the line.</p><p>Heavy smoke cover kept air tankers grounded Sunday and much of Monday.</p><p>Five fires are currently burning in the gold fields, including Haystack Mountain, Henderson Dome and French Gulch, said Paula Webber, a spokeswoman for the territory's wildfire management branch.</p><p>A 300-metre section of one of the fires reached the North Klondike Highway late Saturday night despite efforts from an Ontario fire crew, closing the road briefly.</p><p>Also near Dawson, the Dempster fire jumped the Dempster Highway late Sunday, forcing a closure as crews scrambled to protect homes in the Flat Creek area.</p><p>Fires have burned an estimated 200 square kilometres in the Dawson area. In all, 163 fires have burned a little more than 500 square kilometres across the Yukon.</p><p>Over the last 10 years, an average of about 40 square kilometres burned annually.</p><p>Meanwhile, rain and cooler temperatures were allowing crews to get the upper hand on more wildfires in British Columbia.</p><p>The Town Creek fire near Lillooet, the Kenny Dam and Tatuk Lake fires near Vanderhoof and the Kluskus Lake fires near Quesnel were declared fully contained Monday</p><p>The Seton Lake fire near Lillooet was half contained and the Botaine fire near Lytton is 65 per cent corralled.</p><p>The province's two biggest fires continue near the B.C.-Yukon border. The Swan Lake fire covers 315 square kilometres and is 30 per cent contained, while the Coal River fire is about 258 square kilometres.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CAPRSS-20040705CPCPD5755</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CAPRSS2004</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:4CSX-GYR0-01G6-926Y-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">253760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="480"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Canadian Press (CP)</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2004 Press News Limited, All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationDate day="05" month="07" year="2004"><dateText>July 5, 2004 Monday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newswires & Press Releases</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="company"><classificationItem score="93"><className>YUKON ENERGY CORP </className></classificationItem></classification><classification classificationScheme="ticker"><classificationItem score="93"><className>YUKN (NASDAQ) </className></classificationItem></classification><classification classificationScheme="industry"><classificationItem><className>SIC3433 HEATING EQUIPMENT EX. AM-Sask-Fire-Ban; updates with Garson Lake evacuation; Residents of remote northwest community flee forest fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>GARSON LAKE, Sask.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>GARSON LAKE, Sask. (CP) - Residents of this remote community straddling the northern Alberta-Saskatchewan boundary fled their homes Friday night as a forest fire crept to within 10 kilometres of them.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Early reports indicated that 80 people - 40 residents and 40 firefighters - were forced to leave the area.</p><p>"The fire is not quite six miles north and on the Alberta border,'' said John Cook of Saskatchewan's forest fire management branch.</p><p>Garson Lake is 400 kilometres northwest of Saskatoon. The nearest community is La Loche, about 30 kilometres away over heavy bush and rugged Canadian Shield.</p><p>Earlier Friday, Saskatchewan's environment minister issued a fire ban in the province because of tinder-dry conditions throughout its forests.</p><p>The ban extends from Manitoba to Alberta, north of Highways 3 and 55, and includes all open fires within 4.5 kilometres of provincial forests south of the 58th parallel.</p><p>Only self-contained heating devices or pressurized stoves will be permitted for use during the ban.</p><p>Currently there are approximately 902 firefighters battling 57 fires in the province. Eight of those fires are out of control.</p><p>Those numbers are down slightly from the 63 fires Thursday, 11 of which were out of control.</p><p>On Thursday, four elderly residents of the village of Michel evacuated due to smoke returned to their village, according to Joy Adams Bauer, social services spokesperson.</p><p>Michel is located about 60 kilometres south of La Loche and about 55 kilometres east of the Alberta boundary, where a fire has been blazing only five kilometres away for several days.</p><p>No other communities near fires, including La Loche, BlackPoint, Bear Creek, Turner Lake, Ile a la Crosse and Canoe Lake, are in imminent danger.</p><p>The largest fire in the province is a 100-square kilometre blaze near Apps Lake, about half way between Canoe Narrows and Ile a la Crosse. A 70-square kilometre burn is going on just west of Pinehouse.</p><p>Nicholson said the firefighting effort involves 37 helicopters, 13 air tankers, 22 bulldozers and 12 swamp tractors.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier The reserve is about 200 kilometres northeast of Edmonton, near Canadian Forces Base Cold Lake.</p><p>The transmission line, buried under about 90 centimetres of muskeg, is the main gas line for the reserve.</p><p>Piche said about 80 families who live near the gas line have moved out of their homes and are staying with relatives on the reserve. There are about 1,500 people living on the reserve, which is eight kilometres south of Grand Centre.</p><p>About 100 military personnel from the base and 27 certified firefighters from the band have been battling the fire. It is one of 10 fires which have been burning in the St. Paul region of northeast Alberta for the past several days.</p><p>The crew includes 20 military firefighters who have been waterbombing the flames with a helicopter. More than 100 loads were dumped on the fire Friday.</p><p>Earlier in the week, fires threatened the Metis settlement of Kikino, 150 kilometres northeast of Edmonton, near Lac La Biche. About 50 residents fled their homes Wednesday and spent the night at a community hall in Vilna, about 80 kilometres south of Kikino.</p><p>They returned Thursday after the wind changed direction.</p><p>A fire crew is on standby in case the Kikino fire flares up, said a spokesman for the settlement.</p><p>Drought-like conditions over the summer and unseasonably high temperatures are to blame for the fires.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier "Although insurance can never make up for the <br/>inconvenience that a mass evacuation causes, it can compensate victims for the <br/>inconvenience as well as replace any property that may be damaged by the <br/>fire." <br/>    "Evacuated residents should keep track of their expenses, and in the <br/>event of a claim, contact their insurance agent, broker or company as soon as <br/>possible to report it," said Mr. Rivait. "And anyone seeking general <br/>information about fire insurance coverage, can call our consumer information <br/>centre in Edmonton with their questions." The office can be reached at (780) <br/>423-2212 or toll free at 1-800-377-6378. <br/>    According to reports, the Chisholm fire has already scorched almost 350 <br/>square kilometres, making it the largest of the six out-of-control forest <br/>fires in the province. To save lives and property in the event of natural <br/>disasters like this one, the bureau is calling for the establishment of a <br/>Natural Disaster Reduction Plan. <br/>    "Among other measures, the plan includes creating a Natural Disaster <br/>Protection Fund, which would support projects identified by local communities <br/>to help avoid the damage caused by forest fires of this magnitude," said Mr. <br/>Rivait. "By building firebreaks, that is, clear strips of land designed to <br/>stop the spread of forest fires near urban areas, we can not only save lives, <br/>but also reduce the amount of property that is damaged." </p><p> "As Canada's population continues to grow and disperse into hinterlands, <br/>people will increasingly build homes nestled in trees, making them more <br/>vulnerable to forest fires," added Mr. Rivait. "As we have seen in Alberta, <br/>these fires can affect a large number of people, and have the potential to <br/>affect many more, if we don't focus on mitigation programs that will make our <br/>communities more resistant to natural disasters."</p><p>    The Insurance Bureau of Canada is the national trade association of the <br/>private property and casualty insurance industry. It represents about 200 <br/>companies that provide more than 90 per cent of the non-government home, car <br/>and business insurance in Canada. Visit the media section of the bureau's Web <br/>site at <url normalizedValue="http://www.ibc.ca">www.ibc.ca</url> for more news releases and information.</p><p>    Version franEcaise But the situation became critical late last night and the order to pull out was given, Wilson said.</p><p>The reserve residents were moved to nearby Kenora, where they will spend the next 48 hours, he said.</p><p>If the fire threat continues, they will be bused to Gimli, Man. where the Manitoba government owns an old military base.</p><p>Stayed behind</p><p>The chief of the reserve and his wife - along with three emergency crews - decided to stay behind, Wilson said.</p><p>The fire was 4 kilometres (2.5 miles) wide and 38 kilometres (24 miles) long and was being whipped by high winds northwards to Swan Lake, across from the reserve, Wilson said.</p><p>The blaze almost doubled in size from 4 p.m. to 8.30 p.m. yesterday as it moved north from Sherwood Lake, west of Kenora, to Malachi Lake, where at least five and perhaps 10 cottages were destroyed.</p><p>The Whitedog Reserve is just five kilometres (three miles) north of Malachi, said Dave Stepanik, fire prevention officer for the Kenora District.</p><p>The fire is called Kenora 14 because it is the 14th fire of the season in the district.</p><p>About 65 cottagers were taken out over the weekend and a fire near Fort Frances burned down a barn and killed nine head of cattle, a ministry official said.</p><p>Natural Resources Minister Vince Kerrio yesterday declared an emergency area covering about 1,500 square kilometres affected or threatened by the blaze.</p><p>Any measures</p><p>The order, which permits any measures to be taken to suppress the fire or ensure the safety of residents, remains in effect until next Monday unless conditions improve.</p><p>Kerrio also declared the whole northwestern corner of the province a restricted fire area, which prohibits any open campfires.</p><p>"It's a war, and we hope we're winning in some areas," Wilson said.</p><p>The fire was so hot that much of the water being dropped from planes was evaporating before it hit the ground.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (8:20 a.m. Saturday, July 28) - Parry Sound 33 is still not under control and continues to grow.

In a news release sent out at 12:35 a.m. on July 28, the fire has grown to 7,297 hectares. Due to the southwest winds, the northeast side is the most active part of the fire.

The northeast side of the fire is the focus for Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry water bombers and helicopter bucketing, as it is closest to the rail line and more populated areas.

There has been minimal growth on the southwest end of the fire.

Southwest winds are expected to continue tomorrow, possibly bringing heavy smoke conditions periodically into surrounding commentates and along Highway 69. The fire is approximately seven kilometres west of Highway 69 and three kilometres south of the Pickerel River.

Wildfire crews continue to make progress around the southwest side of the perimeter by laying hose lines and actively attacking hot spots in the Key Harbour. That area is protected and the MNRF does not expect any movement in that area over the next few days.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (11:55 p.m. Thursday, July 26): The Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry reports Parry Sound 33 is still not under control and growing.

According to the ministry in a news release dated 11:55 p.m., Thursday, July 26, by the evening of July 26 there were 45 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 15 are not yet under control, 30 are either being held, under control or being observed. Of the 15 not under control, Parry Sound 33 is one of them.

As of July 26, the fire is estimated at 6,760 hectares and there was minimal grown on the north, west and south end of the fire. The implementation order and all access restriction, including water access restriction, remain in place. The southwest winds are expected to continue today, possibly gusting from 30 to 40 kilometres per hour. Unfortunately, there is minimal precipitation in the forecast.

"Crews continue to make excellent progress around the southwest side of the perimeter, laying hose and working on hotspots north and south of Key River," reads the release."Today's focus was on the north and east flank of the fire, which were once again active due to sustained southern and southwesterly winds. The fire did put on some growth along the east flank, with one area of the fire crossing both Tower Lake and impacting the CN rail in one location."

Continued growth of the fire is expected on the northeast flank today. Water bombers and helicopters worked most of the day halting or slowing the spread of the fire. Values protection, or sprinklers, continue to be placed along Pickerel River and began in Henvey Inlet as a precautionary measure.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (11:55 a.m. Wednesday, July 25): The Ministry of Natural Resources and Fire has expanded Northeast region restricted fire zone.

Due to strong, warmer and drier lake effect winds the ministry required aerial fire suppression yesterday, July 25, as fire activity increased. As a result of the the southwest winds, smoke was pushed across Highway 69 and into some communities to the east of the fire.

Resources yesterday included CL415 water bombers, two bird dog aircraft, heavy helicopters T802 amphibious aircraft and ground crews, the ministry reports.

Additional crews from Mexico arrived on the fire today, bringing the total number of firefighters helping to suppress the fire to 90. Values protection, or sprinklers, will continue to be put in place on structures along the Pickerel River today.

"Given the unpredictability of the fire, all access restrictions, including water restrictions, remain in place for the foreseeable future," reads a ministry press release. "In the interest of public safety, on July 21, 2018 the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry (MNRF)'s Parry Sound district recommended that the communities, municipalities and townships within the area below impose a mandatory evacuation of their residents with boat access only: All areas ranging from the western and northern borders of French River Provincial Park, east to Highway 69, and as far south as the south shore of the Key River; including all residents and members of the public on both the north and south shores of the French River, and the Pickerel River, as well as Hartley Bay."

There is also a recommendation by the ministry Parry Sound district to impose an evacuation alert to all residents within this area who have road access to their residences or cottages. These residents should be prepared to evacuate pending a change in the fire situation.

By the evening of July 25 there were 50 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 16 are not yet under control, 34 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There were two new fires confirmed in the region today. Hearst 14, located approximately 42 kilometres south of Hearst, is two hectares and not yet under control. Two crews provided initial attack on the fire with aerial suppression support. Wawa 11 is being held at 0.1 hectares 75 kilometres southeast of Longlac.

(Tuesday, July 24, 11:10 p.m.):The fire is expected to remain relatively quiet for the next couple of days.

"However, fire conditions and behaviour can change quickly. Crews continue to monitor weather and fire behaviour closely. Residents will see smoke in the area as crews continue suppression efforts. Values protection have been put in place in Key Harbour, along parts of the south side of Pickerel River and along a portion of the train tracks east of the fire."

A total of eight helicopters worked the fire on July 24.

As of July 24 the fire was at 5,612 hectares and still not under control.

The cause of the fire was originally stated as "human" on the MNR's website but that classification has since been removed, McCool said, to avoid public speculation.

"Because the cause is still unknown at this time and it is under investigation."

(11:59 p.m., Monday, July 23): The Key River forest fire, known as Parry Sound 33, is now covering an area of 5,612 hectares and the restricted fire zone has been expanded to north of Rosseau.

According to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services, Parry Sound 33 saw aerial fire suppression again on Monday, July 23. CL415s dropped water on the fire which was remapped at 5,612 hectares. Three heavy helicopters bucketed water to reduce the fire's intensity and co-ordinated with ground crews.

On July 21, the MNRF's Parry Sound district recommended that the communities, municipalities and townships within the area ranging from the western and northern borders of French River Provincial Park, east to Highway 69, and as far south as the south shore of the Key River; including all residents and members of the public on both the north and south shores of the French River, and the Pickerel River, as well as Hartley Bay impose a mandatory evacuation of their residents with boat access only.

There is also a recommendation by the MNRF Parry Sound district to impose an evacuation alert to all residents within this area who have road access to their residences or cottages. These residents should be prepared to evacuate pending a change in the fire situation.

In addition, the MNRF's Sudbury district has recommended that all residents along Hartley Bay Road be placed on an evacuation alert, pending changes to the fire situation.

The Ontario Provincial Police (OPP) and Conservation Officers have been on site helping notify the public of the situation, and facilitating this evacuation.

Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services (AFFES) has also been advised by Ontario Parks that the French River Provincial Park is fully closed west of Highway 69/400. All campers have been or are being evacuated. Ontario Parks has also suspended permit sales for the French River Delta and Pickerel River areas and are restricting entry to park users (everything west of Highway 69/400).

Henvey Inlet First Nation declared a state of emergency as a precautionary measure. As of July 22, the community has successfully and safely evacuated all of its community members, who are receiving accommodation and food.

Due to the extreme fire hazard and the large number of wildfires burning, the MNRF has expanded the Restricted Fire Zone to include some areas of the southern region. The new zone includes areas north of the community of Rosseau, northwest to Caramat, over to the Quebec border along Hwy 11 (to north of Abitibi Canyon) and southeast to Renfrew. This includes Algonquin Park, Parry Sound, Lake Superior Provincial Park, the North Shore of Lake Huron, Wawa, and Hearst. To check out more specific boundaries, visit Ontario.ca/forestfire and click on the interactive fire map.

During a Restricted Fire Zone, the use of open fires - such as campfires, or burning of brush or debris, is restricted. Failure to comply could result in fines of up to $25,000 and three months in jail, as well as financial responsibility for the costs incurred in fighting a forest fire.

Portable gas or propane stoves are permitted for use for cooking or warmth, though they should be closely monitored. Portable charcoal barbecues and Hibachis are not permitted unless within 100 metres of a dwelling, or within an organized campground.

Commercial campground operators may allow their guests to enjoy campfires during a Restricted Fire Zone period provided they meet certain conditions.

The Restricted Fire Zone is a temporary measure to reduce the number of new human-caused wildfires as the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ontario MNRF expects the elevated forest fire hazard to continue into the foreseeable future.

By the evening of July 23 there were 55 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 21 are not yet under control, 34 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There was only one new start in the region today. Sudbury 92 located near Johnnie Lake in Killarney Provincial Park covers 0.1 of a hectare and is already under control.

Residents in Greater Victoria may see and smell smoke in the air over the next few days.

Prescribed burning at the Department of National Defence's Rocky Point property began on Wednesday and is expected to occur for about four to six days between mid-September and the beginning of October.

According to a news release from CFB Esquimalt, Garry oak ecosystems at Rocky Point benefit "significantly" from fire. Without fire, the grassland ecosystems are taken over by conifers such as pine and fir trees as well as invasive plants. The encroaching wildlife reduces the area of Garry oak habitat and increases the risk of uncontrolled fire at Rocky Point.

READ ALSO: DND burns 14 hectares to protect Garry oaks

To improve and restore military training areas and the habitat for rare native plants as well as reduce the risk of forest fire, the prescribed burn is being done over 20.5 hectares of land on the property.

Provincial fire crews are directly supervising the burn during optimal conditions.

Langford Happy Valley and surrounding area, smoke in the air is from prescribed burning out at Rocky Point DND property. Potentially for the next three days. #yyj #langford #DnD pic.twitter.com/q8nPp37VrW— Langford Fire Rescue (@LangfordFire) September 11, 2019

Langford Fire Rescue posted on Facebook and Twitter that smoke seen Wednesday evening in Langford's Happy Valley and surrounding areas was from the prescribed burn and could last for the next three days.

The City of Colwood also posted on its Facebook page saying smoke in the air around Colwood is likely due to the burn.

On Wednesday, Metchosin Fire Chief Stephanie Dunlop shared photos of the burn, saying it will be happening for the next three days.

A8</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire in Timmins closes connecting highway Crews bring blaze under control to avoid evacuations</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Karl Sepkowski SPECIAL TO THE STAR</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>TIMMINS</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>TIMMINS - A forest fire in the southeast end of this city closed a highway and at one point had firefighters considering the evacuation of about 150 residents from a trailer park.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Timmins hospital was also put on alert because of the threat of smoke to patients with respiratory problems.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Timmins Fire Department, along with five three-member crews from the natural resources ministry and volunteers from the Mountjoy fire brigade, were able to bring the fire under control by 6 p.m. yesterday, eliminating the need for evacuations.</p><p>Four natural resources' water bombing aircraft used to attack the 65-hectare fire were sent back to their respective bases last night.</p><p>But Highway 655, which connects Timmins with Highway 11 and other Northern Ontario centres such as Kapuskasing and Cochrane, remained closed last night.</p><p>A Timmins police spokesman said the highway would remain closed until all hot spots in the burned-out area had been soaked with water.</p><p>Traffic that normally uses Highway 655 was routed along Highway 101 and away from the fire scene.</p><p>Forests across Northern Ontario are tinder dry because of a lack of rain and very little snow cover this past winter.</p><p>So far this spring, 114 fires have broken out, compared with four a year ago.</p><p>One of the largest, a 2,400-hectare fire 140 kilometres northwest of Thunder Bay, continued to burn out of control yesterday. Forest Service said. "The winds were going our way."</p><p>In some cases, residents found only burned out hulks that once were their cars and a single chimney standing in the space formerly occupied by their homes.</p><p>Dana Simpson was one of the lucky ones to find his home still standing.</p><p>Simpson, who was busy hosing down the trees around his home with water obtained from a private service, said a wide concrete patio surrounding his house saved it from the flames.</p><p>"There is definitely a sad feeling for the people that lost their homes," he said.</p><p>About 275 people were fighting the blaze that has scorched 3,000 hectares of forest and brush running up the steep terrain of the rural suburbs.</p><p>Meanwhile, the forest service largely ruled out a lightning strike as the spark that ignited the blaze last week.</p><p>Fire crews thought they were getting a handle on the blaze Monday, but the wind changed and sent flames roaring back toward Penticton's eastern subdivisions.</p><p>Firefighters had to be lifted to safety by helicopter or guided out when they lost touch with the fire's direction.</p><p>The firefighters, exhausted by high temperatures and long hours, were helped by a fleet of water bombers including two giant Martin Mars flying boats.</p><p>The planes can carry 27,000 litres of water -- five times as much as smaller tankers.</p><p>Initial estimates put the cost of fighting the fire so far at $1 million.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>The charred remains of a car beside what once was a house just outside of Penticton Tuesday. urn:contentItem:5P84-SPG1-F105-645D-00000-00Fire smoke in northwest Ontario prompts evacuation of First Nation members2017-08-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisNEWSFire smoke in northwest Ontario prompts evacuation of First Nation members

Smoke from an increasing number of forest fires in northwestern Ontario has prompted the evacuation of a First Nation in the region, officials said Tuesday.

Deb MacLean, a fire information officer with the province's forest fire fighting centre in Dryden, Ont., said there have been a rapidly rising number of fires in the region, with up to 30 new fires a day and a current total of 155 blazes in the area.

While there aren't any communities that are imminently at risk because of the fires, smoke has been affecting communities in the area, she said.

That smoke, as well as an unrelated power outage, was what led the Nibinamik First Nation to declare an emergency and ask for an evacuation on Saturday night, the community's chief said.

The Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry said it had evacuated 354 people by airplane from the First Nation since Saturday.

Chief Johnny Yellowhead said those community members, as well as 79 others from the First Nation, have been set up in hotels in Kapuskasing, Ont.

"It's very overwhelming, there's a lot of distress," said Yellowhead. "People are worried about their pets and their campgrounds, their personal belongings ... it's (frustrating) for the community members, they want to go home."

Seven people from the First Nation volunteered to stay behind to help the Ministry of Natural Resources in its efforts to monitor and maintain the community, Yellowhead said. Two contractors, two nurses and one ministry employee were also still in the community, the ministry said.

MacLean said it had been a slow year overall for fires in the region but August has seen a high number of fires in a condensed area.

"In 2017, we had a quiet spring and early summer, and then we started to get storm systems tracking through after a period of dry weather," she explained. Lightning from the storms is what had sparked some of the fires.

While forecasted rain is expected to help firefighters battle the blaze, MacLean called rain a "double-edged sword" because of the lightning that could accompany it.

She said the risk for fires will range from high to extreme during the upcoming weekend.

Firefighting aircraft have been called in from Quebec and Minnesota to help fight the blazes in the area, she said.

For the Nibinamik First Nation, it's not the first time that the community has dealt with the impact of a forest fire. In 1993, Yellowhead said a fire came up to the community, burning two outhouses.

urn:contentItem:5JPD-28S1-JBVR-32PH-00000-00Humans are leading cause of wildfires in Canada: scientist2016-05-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisPRAIRIES/BC,NATIONALHumans are leading cause of wildfires in Canada: scientistHumans leading cause of wildfires:scientistLiam CaseyThe Canadian Press

Humans are the leading cause of wildfires in Canada, says a forest fire researcher who believes the latest blaze that has ripped through parts of Fort McMurray, Alta., is no exception.

Mike Flannigan, a professor of wildland fires at the University of Alberta, says the fire's proximity to the city, as well as data that shows there were no lightning strikes in the area, lead him to believe the cause of the fire was likely human.

"And in spring it's heavily loaded on the side of people-caused fires," Flannigan said.

An average of 1,200 wildfires are reported in Alberta each year, and half of those fires are caused by humans, according to the National Fire Database. Lightning is the second-leading cause with 47 per cent.

Officials were still investigating the cause of the latest fire, which remained out of control on Wednesday as it raged around Fort McMurray, a city of about 80,000 people located 435 kilometres northeast of Edmonton.

However, Flannigan said weather conditions in Western Canada have been perfect for wildfires as the warm, dry winter has led to an abundance of dead, dry leaves and wood ready to light up.

"It's really extreme conditions," he said, adding that the low humidity and lack of green vegetation combined with windy conditions contributed to the incredibly intense fire in the northern Alberta city.

"Spring fires are common after the snow melts and before things green up and get lush," Flannigan said.

"There is a two- or three-week window where they occur."

He said the biggest variable at this point is the wind, which gusted up to 40 km/h on Tuesday, the day the city was evacuated.

"Shifting winds is a challenging problem for fighting fires," he said. "You want people to be safe and this includes the firefighters and you don't want to put them in harm's way."

A pilot died in 2011 when his firefighting helicopter crashed near Slave Lake, Alta., and another pilot died last year in a water-bomber crash while fighting a wildfire near Cold Lake, Alta. However, there have been no civilian fatalities because of a forest fire since 1938, said Tim Lynham, a forest fire researcher with Natural Resources Canada.

Scientists, however, are worried about the future.

Forest fires are a natural phenomenon, Lynham said, and are beneficial ecologically, returning valuable nutrients to the soil that helps a natural rebirth. He said fires naturally occur in forests every 150 to 250 years.

"But the fires are happening more often so forests might not be able to cope with that and might not be able to regenerate properly," Lynham said.

Scientists at Natural Resources Canada predict forest fires will double within 50 to 100 years.

urn:contentItem:7W7M-YF11-2R6R-512X-00000-00Water bomber battling B.C. forest fire crashes into Okanagan Lake2009-07-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisGENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWSWater bomber battling B.C. forest fire crashes into Okanagan LakeCP

KELOWNA, B.C. _ One of six water bombers battling the Terrace Mountain fire near Kelowna, B.C., has crashed into Okanagan Lake.

Transportation Safety Board spokesman Bill Yearwood said Saturday the incident occurred just as the aircraft touched down to pick up water.

''The pilot was not injured to the extent that he was left incapacitated and was able to extricate himself,'' Yearwood said of the man who is being treated in hospital for minor injuries.

''I'm hoping to speak to the pilot later today when he's able to,'' he said.

The water bomber sank to the bottom of the lake in an area where about half of the 2,200 evacuees were returning home after crews managed to contain 25 per cent of the fire.

The amphibious aircraft drops water and retardant on fires and has wheels so it can operate on land and in water.

It's owned by the Conair Group of Abbotsford, B.C.

Conair general manager Rick Pedersen said the pilot has worked for the company for 10 years.

''He's very experienced in air tanker operations, both amphibious as this was as well as our other tanker operations.''

Pedersen said the company has contracted six such aircraft to the B.C. government as part of a fire-fighting effort in the Okanagan.

All six bombers are based in Alberta, from where they are on loan to B.C., Pedersen said.

He said the company is not releasing the pilot's name for now.

''We're still supporting the pilot and his family so we'll get through that first.''

Residents who are coming back to their homes are still on evacuation alert and could be faced with leaving yet again if the fire flares up.

The fire now covers about 45 square kilometres.

urn:contentItem:5WCR-F1S1-F103-315F-00000-00Fruitvale mill affected by downturn in lumber market2019-06-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisNEWSFruitvale mill affected by downturn in lumber marketSheri Regnier

A family-run mill, and key West Kootenay employer, has rode out many storms in 60+ years of operations in Fruitvale.

So this latest downturn in the lumber industry across British Columbia - due to poor market conditions, disastrous wildfires, and ongoing insect infestations - is one more challenge that ATCO Wood Products is prepared to face through progressive planning.

"At ATCO Wood Products, we are not immune to these phenomenons," Chief Executive Officer Scott Weatherford told the Trail Times. "We are evaluating market conditions day by day, and charting a new path weekly to weather these challenges."

As a producer of softwood veneer for the plywood industry, ATCO supplies a small, niche product to a market that is also presently in an economic downswing.

Much of the company's timber comes from Crown land harvesting operations. So the increased log cost cited by other B.C. mills as a reason for their cutbacks, has affected ATCO's bottom line as well.

That means the Fruitvale business has been forced to run fewer days a week, on occasion.

"Prices and demand for our product are down," Weatherford said.

"And we have been forced to curtail operations intermittently, depending on market conditions each week (such as) running three or four days per week instead of the normal five, some weeks."

On Monday, Canfor Corp., announced it would curtail operations at all but one of its mills for two to six weeks due to market conditions. The company also closed its mill in Vavenby (North Thompson River) last week, eliminating 172 jobs.

On Tuesday, Norbord Inc. said operations would be suspended at its 100 Mile House mill indefinitely, impacting 160 employees.

Last month, Interfor, which operates sawmills in Grand Forks and Castlegar, said it was reducing production and shutting the mills down for several unspecified days in June.

"We're also keeping a watchful eye on the weather, and hoping that the forecasts for a third and terrible forest fire season do not come to pass," Weatherford said.

"Wood products markets are cyclical, and at over 60-years old, our company has weathered many of these cycles.

"While we are working through challenging times, we're also using the opportunity to innovate, learn, and reinvest to make us stronger to weather future cycles."

With no foreseeable end to the impact of beetle infestations and wildfire, the immediate solution lies in stringent industry practices.

By implementing forest management and harvesting plans, ATCO's forestry team is now focused on managing beetle outbreaks in Douglas Fir, as they did with Mountain Pine Beetle in years past.

"We've also had some luck in our region during the last two years, as the forest fire season has not affected our company to the same degree than many other forest companies in central and northern B.C have been affected," said Weatherford.

"However, we have a very resourceful team, a very high quality product, and have been reinvesting in our Fruitvale operations for many years to improve our operating efficiency," he added.

"Together, this has helped us mitigate a small portion, but not all, of the challenging market conditions, and helped us avoid full curtailments."

Challenging market conditions boil down to lack luster demand for wood products in North America, which causes prices to drop.

Weatherford says lumber prices have fallen over 50 per cent from spring 2018 highs, making it difficult for mills to find customers for all of their production, which leads to operational cutbacks.

"In addition, imports of wood products from overseas (Asia, South America, and Europe) are further adding to the supply/demand imbalance in the marketplace," he explained.

"Exacerbating the tough market conditions for producers in B.C., are very high and increasing log costs. This is due to the lag in the formula that is used to calculate stumpage payments, or revenue paid by forest companies for timber to the Crown for timber harvested from Crown land."

Current stumpage rates are partly based on the wood product prices from last year.

"The result of all of this is that the market price of many wood products right now, does not cover the cost of harvesting timber and converting that timber into lumber, plywood, and OSB (engineered wood)," Weatherford said.

"And thus, mills are curtailing to reduce their financial losses."

Smoke may be visible in areas north and northeast of the fire due to winds from the south which may impact visibility along Highway 69 and local communities.

Please call 511 for HWY closure information. #forestfires #ontario pic.twitter.com/pZ7WpivbJT - ONForestFires (@ONforestfires) July 29, 2018

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE (8:26 a.m. Sunday, July 29) - Parry Sound 33 had minimal growth yesterday increasing in size from 7,297 to 7,651.

In a news release sent out by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry shortly before midnight on Saturday, July 28, the fire is still listed as not under control.

Water bombers and helicopters worked most of the day on July 28, limiting movement among most areas of the fire's perimeter with generally good results.

The southwest winds are expected to continue today, possibly bringing heavy smoke conditions periodically into surrounding communities along Highway 69. The fire remains approximately seven kilometres west of Highway 69 and three kilometres south of the Pickerel River and is nearly 100 kilometres north of Parry Sound.

For most of Saturday, July 28, winds from the southwest continued, keeping the northeast side as the most active part of the fire. Priority remains along the northeast side of the fire with fingers extending toward the CN rail line as minimal movement occurred across the tracks. Additionally, there was minimal growth along the southwest portion of the fire.

Hose lay and containment will continue along the northern portion as crews look to secure that area.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (8:20 a.m. Saturday, July 28) - Parry Sound 33 is still not under control and continues to grow.

In a news release sent out at 12:35 a.m. on July 28, the fire has grown to 7,297 hectares. Due to the southwest winds, the northeast side is the most active part of the fire.

The northeast side of the fire is the focus for Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry water bombers and helicopter bucketing, as it is closest to the rail line and more populated areas.

There has been minimal growth on the southwest end of the fire.

Southwest winds are expected to continue tomorrow, possibly bringing heavy smoke conditions periodically into surrounding commentates and along Highway 69. The fire is approximately seven kilometres west of Highway 69 and three kilometres south of the Pickerel River.

Wildfire crews continue to make progress around the southwest side of the perimeter by laying hose lines and actively attacking hot spots in the Key Harbour. That area is protected and the MNRF does not expect any movement in that area over the next few days.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (11:55 p.m. Thursday, July 26): The Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry reports Parry Sound 33 is still not under control and growing.

According to the ministry in a news release dated 11:55 p.m., Thursday, July 26, by the evening of July 26 there were 45 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 15 are not yet under control, 30 are either being held, under control or being observed. Of the 15 not under control, Parry Sound 33 is one of them.

As of July 26, the fire is estimated at 6,760 hectares and there was minimal grown on the north, west and south end of the fire. The implementation order and all access restriction, including water access restriction, remain in place. The southwest winds are expected to continue today, possibly gusting from 30 to 40 kilometres per hour. Unfortunately, there is minimal precipitation in the forecast.

"Crews continue to make excellent progress around the southwest side of the perimeter, laying hose and working on hotspots north and south of Key River," reads the release."Today's focus was on the north and east flank of the fire, which were once again active due to sustained southern and southwesterly winds. The fire did put on some growth along the east flank, with one area of the fire crossing both Tower Lake and impacting the CN rail in one location."

Continued growth of the fire is expected on the northeast flank today. Water bombers and helicopters worked most of the day halting or slowing the spread of the fire. Values protection, or sprinklers, continue to be placed along Pickerel River and began in Henvey Inlet as a precautionary measure.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (11:55 a.m. Wednesday, July 25): The Ministry of Natural Resources and Fire has expanded Northeast region restricted fire zone.

Due to strong, warmer and drier lake effect winds the ministry required aerial fire suppression yesterday, July 25, as fire activity increased. As a result of the the southwest winds, smoke was pushed across Highway 69 and into some communities to the east of the fire.

Resources yesterday included CL415 water bombers, two bird dog aircraft, heavy helicopters T802 amphibious aircraft and ground crews, the ministry reports.

Additional crews from Mexico arrived on the fire today, bringing the total number of firefighters helping to suppress the fire to 90. Values protection, or sprinklers, will continue to be put in place on structures along the Pickerel River today.

"Given the unpredictability of the fire, all access restrictions, including water restrictions, remain in place for the foreseeable future," reads a ministry press release. "In the interest of public safety, on July 21, 2018 the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry (MNRF)'s Parry Sound district recommended that the communities, municipalities and townships within the area below impose a mandatory evacuation of their residents with boat access only: All areas ranging from the western and northern borders of French River Provincial Park, east to Highway 69, and as far south as the south shore of the Key River; including all residents and members of the public on both the north and south shores of the French River, and the Pickerel River, as well as Hartley Bay."

There is also a recommendation by the ministry Parry Sound district to impose an evacuation alert to all residents within this area who have road access to their residences or cottages. These residents should be prepared to evacuate pending a change in the fire situation.

By the evening of July 25 there were 50 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 16 are not yet under control, 34 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There were two new fires confirmed in the region today. Hearst 14, located approximately 42 kilometres south of Hearst, is two hectares and not yet under control. Two crews provided initial attack on the fire with aerial suppression support. Wawa 11 is being held at 0.1 hectares 75 kilometres southeast of Longlac.

(Tuesday, July 24, 11:10 p.m.):The fire is expected to remain relatively quiet for the next couple of days.

"However, fire conditions and behaviour can change quickly. Crews continue to monitor weather and fire behaviour closely. Residents will see smoke in the area as crews continue suppression efforts. Values protection have been put in place in Key Harbour, along parts of the south side of Pickerel River and along a portion of the train tracks east of the fire."

A total of eight helicopters worked the fire on July 24.

As of July 24 the fire was at 5,612 hectares and still not under control.

The cause of the fire was originally stated as "human" on the MNR's website but that classification has since been removed, McCool said, to avoid public speculation.

"Because the cause is still unknown at this time and it is under investigation."

(11:59 p.m., Monday, July 23): The Key River forest fire, known as Parry Sound 33, is now covering an area of 5,612 hectares and the restricted fire zone has been expanded to north of Rosseau.

According to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services, Parry Sound 33 saw aerial fire suppression again on Monday, July 23. CL415s dropped water on the fire which was remapped at 5,612 hectares. Three heavy helicopters bucketed water to reduce the fire's intensity and co-ordinated with ground crews.

On July 21, the MNRF's Parry Sound district recommended that the communities, municipalities and townships within the area ranging from the western and northern borders of French River Provincial Park, east to Highway 69, and as far south as the south shore of the Key River; including all residents and members of the public on both the north and south shores of the French River, and the Pickerel River, as well as Hartley Bay impose a mandatory evacuation of their residents with boat access only.

There is also a recommendation by the MNRF Parry Sound district to impose an evacuation alert to all residents within this area who have road access to their residences or cottages. These residents should be prepared to evacuate pending a change in the fire situation.

In addition, the MNRF's Sudbury district has recommended that all residents along Hartley Bay Road be placed on an evacuation alert, pending changes to the fire situation.

The Ontario Provincial Police (OPP) and Conservation Officers have been on site helping notify the public of the situation, and facilitating this evacuation.

Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services (AFFES) has also been advised by Ontario Parks that the French River Provincial Park is fully closed west of Highway 69/400. All campers have been or are being evacuated. Ontario Parks has also suspended permit sales for the French River Delta and Pickerel River areas and are restricting entry to park users (everything west of Highway 69/400).

Henvey Inlet First Nation declared a state of emergency as a precautionary measure. As of July 22, the community has successfully and safely evacuated all of its community members, who are receiving accommodation and food.

Due to the extreme fire hazard and the large number of wildfires burning, the MNRF has expanded the Restricted Fire Zone to include some areas of the southern region. The new zone includes areas north of the community of Rosseau, northwest to Caramat, over to the Quebec border along Hwy 11 (to north of Abitibi Canyon) and southeast to Renfrew. This includes Algonquin Park, Parry Sound, Lake Superior Provincial Park, the North Shore of Lake Huron, Wawa, and Hearst. To check out more specific boundaries, visit Ontario.ca/forestfire and click on the interactive fire map.

During a Restricted Fire Zone, the use of open fires - such as campfires, or burning of brush or debris, is restricted. Failure to comply could result in fines of up to $25,000 and three months in jail, as well as financial responsibility for the costs incurred in fighting a forest fire.

Portable gas or propane stoves are permitted for use for cooking or warmth, though they should be closely monitored. Portable charcoal barbecues and Hibachis are not permitted unless within 100 metres of a dwelling, or within an organized campground.

Commercial campground operators may allow their guests to enjoy campfires during a Restricted Fire Zone period provided they meet certain conditions.

The Restricted Fire Zone is a temporary measure to reduce the number of new human-caused wildfires as the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ontario MNRF expects the elevated forest fire hazard to continue into the foreseeable future.

By the evening of July 23 there were 55 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 21 are not yet under control, 34 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There was only one new start in the region today. Sudbury 92 located near Johnnie Lake in Killarney Provincial Park covers 0.1 of a hectare and is already under control.

TRAVEL RESTRICTIONS

Pursuant to the Emergency Area Order signed July 21, 2018, an Implementation Order has been issued by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry prohibiting access and travel in portions of Parry Sound District where there are public safety hazards as a result of increased fire activity from Parry Sound 33.

The order restricts travel, access and use in an identified area and may be modified regularly to reflect changing fire conditions. This measure has been put in place to ensure public safety while allowing fire personnel to safely and effectively suppress the fires in the identified area.

All travel and use on the French River waterway, Pickerel River (West of Hwy 69/400), Henvey Inlet, Key River basin, and all associated tributaries that access these river systems, including all access from Georgian Bay, and all islands on Georgian Bay within the French River Provincial Park boundaries, Dokis Island system, and Puddick island and all islands north of Henvey Inlet near shore is prohibited.

All access roads west of Hwy 69/400, from Henvey Inlet north to the French River area are closed.

If a member of the public believes that access within the restricted travel area is necessary for nonrecreational purposes, please call to 705-746-4201 to request a travel authorization permit. MNRF will review the request for access based on the rationale provided, local fire activity, and the potential fire risk.

urn:contentItem:4SSN-WCG0-TX4V-K04W-00000-00All-terrain vehicles blamed for forest fire in central Manitoba2008-06-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSAll-terrain vehicles blamed for forest fire in central ManitobaCP

WINNIPEG _ Investigators have concluded an all-terrain vehicle likely caused a fire that tore through the Sandilands Provincial Forest in late May, consuming 34 square kilometres of land.

Based on evidence, witness statements and burn patterns, investigators believe the May 24 blaze was started by peat moss that had become trapped under the muffler of an ATV, where it heated up and then fell into the grass.

''It's like hot coals falling off,'' said Tom Mirus, the province's fire program manager.

Mirus said investigators are ''about 90 per cent sure'' of the cause, but can't pinpoint exactly who's responsible.

''We know where, we know what, we don't know who,'' he said. ''And probably the person that started the fire didn't even know it. The stuff would fall off their machines and they wouldn't be any the wiser.''

A provincial spokesman said there was no way to definitively link the fire to a poker derby that attracted roughly 600 ATV users to Sandilands the day the fire began. He said many people use the forest's trails regularly.

The Sandilands fire ran up roughly $250,000 in firefighting costs, said Mirus, while the cost of the blaze in terms of forest burned isn't yet known.

The province is currently reviewing its Crown lands policy on ATV use, and hopes to finish the review by fall, he said.

Reports of the fire drew angry messages on ATV websites in late May from fans of the vehicles who felt they were being unfairly targeted.

ATVPathfinders.net owner Kevin Druet argued at the time that most all-terrain vehicles are well-maintained, but said drivers do need to take safety precautions.

''Do ATVers need to be more diligent about making sure their mufflers don't have any dry grass packed around them? Absolutely,'' he said.

(Winnipeg Free Press)
