urn:contentItem:5P5T-4RM1-JDH3-G2YR-00000-00Mexican firefighters arrive in Chilliwack to join the wildfire battle2017-08-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisNEWSMexican firefighters arrive in Chilliwack to join the wildfire battlePaul Henderson

More than 100 firefighters from Mexico arrived in Chilliwack Wednesday in the first step en route to the B.C. interior to help battle the wildfires.

The wildfire personnel arrived at the RCMP's Pacific Regional Training Centre (PRTC), stayed overnight in the hotel, and were set to begin orientation early Thursday.

The deployment is the latest help from outside the province aimed to help battle the hundreds of wildfires in what is turning out to be one of the worse wildfire seasons in B.C. ever .

Since April 1, 491,000 hectares have burned across the province, sending this season over the 483,000 hectares burned in 1961. Only 1958 was even worse - 855,000 hectares burned that year.

The provincial government announced on Tuesday that because of the sustained hot and dry weather, which continues to exacerbate the already busy summer wildfire season, additional firefighting resources from the United States and Mexico were engaged to assist the BC Wildfire Service.

The 108 wildfire personnel from Mexico are scheduled to be deployed to the Interior on Friday. This is the first time Mexican personnel have assisted B.C., although they have been employed many times in Alberta.

This is in addition to 27 firefighters from Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan who were brought into B.C. in addition to crews from Ontario that arrived last weekend. These firefighters were imported from Ontario as part of the cross-border Great Lakes Forest Fire Compact.

"Given the severity of B.C. wildfires this year, we greatly appreciate the ability to draw on personnel from beyond our borders," said Doug Donaldson, Minister of Forests, Lands, Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development. "We thank all incoming crews, as well as all our B.C. crews and contractors in their ongoing firefighting efforts."

The firefighters from Mexico and the U.S. are trained to the standards of the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre and will be valuable as they assist with B.C.'s current wildfire situation. The cost of bringing in the international resources will be covered by the Province of B.C.

Hot and dry weather conditions have kept a persistently high fire danger rating throughout B.C. Firefighting crews are on standby in all six of B.C.'s fire centres in preparation for an anticipated increase in fire starts over the next few days due to unsettled weather in the forecast, which may bring lightning.

To report a new wildfire or an open burning violation, call 1 800 663-5555 toll-free or *5555 on a cellphone.

(CP) _ An unpredictable forest fire left the status of the main highway into northern Alberta's largest city a question mark Monday for anyone returning from the long weekend.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Highway 63 into Fort McMurray was opened for a few hours in the morning, only to be shut down again when the blaze flared.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>An alternate route, secondary Highway 881, remained an option for light passenger vehicles, but many motorists were unwilling to take the rough road _ unpaved for 130 kilometres of its winding route.</p><p> Traffic's backed up in town,'' said Nina Gostevskyh, manager of the Grassland Motel, about 130 kilometres northeast of Edmonton. I guess everybody is just waiting to hear when the road will open up again. People are parked at gas stations.''</p><p>Bob Gartshore, a Fort McMurray resident returning from Red Deer, Alta., decided to spend the night at the Lac La Biche Inn, about 190 kilometres south of home.</p><p> We're not overly concerned,'' said Gartshore. We'll wait till the road opens. We'll get there when we can.''</p><p>RCMP and Alberta forestry officials first closed the highway early Sunday morning as thick smoke made visibility difficult.</p><p>The 500 firefighters battling the stubborn blaze, which grew 10,000 hectares Monday to 70,000 hectares, weren't getting much help from the weather, said Patrick Loewen, a wildfire information officer with the province.</p><p> Precipitation has been minimal and the winds are changing . . . which changes the head of the fire.''</p><p>Crews were using 48 bulldozers, 28 helicopters and three air-tanker units to fight the fire, about 400 kilometres north of Edmonton.</p><p>Another fire that destroyed a home and a cabin and forced the evacuation of 70 families Saturday was also still burning near Smoky Lake, Alta.</p><p>The evacuation was lifted and many residents returned home, but a state of emergency remained and they were told to remain on self-alert, said Loewen. That means it was up to people to keep an eye on the situation and leave if necessary.</p><p>The fire, burning about 100 kilometres northeast of Edmonton, had reached about 3,000 hectares and was still regarded as out of control, he said.</p><p>Light rain and cool weather Sunday had helped fighters temporarily subdue the blaze, but warmer, drier weather Monday increased concerns of renewed flareups.</p><p> It's not under control yet, but we are hoping it will be later tonight,'' Smoky Lake County manager Cary Smigerowsky said late Monday evening. It's going well. We're trying to get it surrounded, but we can't say we have it under control yet.''</p><p>Smoke from both the fires filled the northern Alberta air.</p><p>In Edmonton, a dreary cloud of smoke enveloped the city shortly before sunset, reducing visibility and prompting local health official to issue warnings to anyone with respiratory problems.</p><p>The Edmonton fire department received more than 250 calls from city residents concerned there might be a fire in their area.</p><p> We are just swamped,'' said Platoon Capt. Darrell Payne. Everyone thinks their ravine is on fire.''</p><p>Fire bans remained in place across much of the province Monday as at least 10 fires were still burning.</p><p>The blazes emphasized the high fire hazard that exists in the province due to extreme dryness. Alberta Sustainable Resources was asking people to take extra precautions due to the dry conditions.</p><p>(Edmonton Sun)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata (CP) - A state of emergency was declared in Timmins as a fire raged through a forest just three kilometres from the heart of the city.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"It was like a big mushroom cloud and it was crowning - jumping from treetop to treetop - so you almost see the flames from town,'' said Ben Legouffe, information officer for the Ministry of Natural Resources in Timmins.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"I knew right away it was time to get to work.''</p><p>One house on Baker Lake was damaged. No serious injuries have been reported.</p><p>Late Thursday, the fire was not under control and firefighters were concentrating on saving property and lives, police said. Another 10 crews were to arrive today from the Ministry.</p><p>About 500 people - the entire population of two trailer parks along the Mattagami River, about 400 units - were evacuated soon after the fire broke out at 4.30 p.m., west of the city.</p><p>About 12 homes near Baker Lake, in the fire's path, were also evacuated.</p><p>More evacuations were expected as the fire headed northwest and Mayor Vic Power declared a state of emergency.</p><p>Burning along a 200-hectare front, the fire jumped the 120-metre wide Mattagami River and the highway.</p><p>Legouffe said the fire was threatening to destroy the two trailer parks and a heavily built up area containing many homes and cottages.</p><p>"Our biggest problem is the wind,'' said Timmins Fire Chief Lester Cudmore.</p><p>"But we have set up a line at the trailer parks and made a commitment to save them.</p><p>"The smoke density is so great we have to keep pulling our people out because they can't breathe,'' Cudmore said. "The Ministry of Natural Resources is handling the fire in the bush.</p><p>"We can't go into the bush because there's always a danger of crowning and the firefighters could be trapped.''</p><p>"It's pretty frightening, for sure,'' said Insp. Ted O'Connor, of Timmins City Police.</p><p>Three water bombers had been brought in to help quell the flames during the afternoon and eight crews from local fire departments and Ministry fire crews were working on the ground.</p><p>Weather looked to be on the side of the firefighters. Rain was expected overnight and the wind was beginning to die down as dusk fell.</p><p>But grave concerns were held for Malette's sawmill as the fire raged alongside it's fence. But it was untouched as the fire veered and went around it.</p><p>Nevertheless, members of the Timmins Fire Department and Malette firefighters doused the lumber, including a $7-million pile, to help keep the danger down.</p><p>The evacuees were taken to the McIntyre Community Building in Timmins.</p><p>"They are pretty upset and concerned,'' said Kathy Worman, branch manager form the Timmins and District Red Cross society. "Obviously the fire could destroy everything they own.''</p><p>She said some people had managed to gather some belongings and valuables, before they fled their homes.</p><p>"And we've got a few pets here. We've got a couple of parrots, some dogs and cats. The parrots are talkative but they're keeping the kids amused.''</p><p>Edith Pfanner said the thing that bothers her the most is not knowing what's happening.</p><p>"You go through upset and then you start to feel tired, right now I'm just more or less going on my nerves.</p><p>"This is a day I wish I could go back to bed and sleep right through.''</p><p>Trailer park residents were told to leave all behind and go to the evacuation station. Pfanner brought her pets along and "my mother's 25th anniversary plate, she's been married over 50 years now, things like that you just grab. Sentimental value.''</p><p>It's the first forest fire of the season in the area but Legouffe said the fires don't usually burn so close to the city.</p><p>Just a year ago, residents along the Mattagami River battled the worst flooding in more than 20 years.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5VJ1-NDD1-JDH1-C4S3-00000-00Peter Heller's thriller 'The River' follows two friends on a tumultuous wilderness adventure2019-02-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisWHATSONPg. 0Peter Heller's thriller 'The River' follows two friends on a tumultuous wilderness adventure

Peter Heller is the author of three novels, including "Celine," which I reviewed in May, 2017, about a cantankerous female detective on the trail of a missing person in Colorado. I was hoping that Celine would be a series but "The River" runs through entirely new territory: northern Manitoba. Two young men are spending a month canoeing the Maskwa River, ending up at Hudson Bay.

I was curious to follow their route on Google Maps but found no river by that name, though there is a Moskwa River in central Manitoba. This is how we read now, with Google standing by. I suspect that Heller was using the Winisk River or Nelson River as a model. (In the acknowledgments, he does thank the people of Peawanuk, at the mouth of the Winisk, for their hospitality.)

In any case, this end-of-summer river trek soon loses its idyllic innocence. Wynn and Jack, best friends since starting university together, smell smoke, so they stop to climb a tree and realize that a forest fire is in the distance. Then they run into two Texan rednecks busy getting drunk. The duo has a motor on their canoe but is in no rush about the smoke. The two lads continue down the lake only to hear shouting, an argument between an unseen man and woman.

The next day, the plume of smoke has widened to a cloud bank and is definitely closer. Both know the power of a forest fire to jump a river and ignite anything in front of it, a firestorm. But just as they speed up their paddling nearing some rapids that must be portaged, they spot a green canoe with a man paddling heedless of the danger ahead. The man lands his canoe and begins to cry. " 'My wife,' he said finally. 'She's missing. Gone.' "

So, the moral crisis begins. Do they believe Pierre who claims his wife wandered off in the fog? Go back to try to find her and let him get to civilization - 10 days away - and report her missing? And what was the couple arguing about?

They do retrace their route despite the fire threat and find a woman, badly injured in the weeds near a campsite. It becomes clear that Maia was not attacked by a bear, their first assumption, but beaten by Pierre and left to die. So, now they need to get themselves and this victim to safety and hope that Pierre is not lurking behind the next bend with his shotgun. Oh and not to mention avoiding the rednecks and the fire as well.

Peter Heller has crafted another fine thriller but this is more literary than genre writing. In flashbacks we learn about Jack's mother's death in a trail-riding accident near their ranch. Both lads are as addicted to good books as they are to outdoor adventuring: canoes, fishing, cooking over an open fire, shaking the frost off the tent in the morning. They're as likely to quote poetry as tease each other in the face of a crisis. Wynn chews tobacco and feels homesick for the Vermont countryside where he grew up.

Heller in both books uses the wilderness as more than the setting, rather as a force that can drive a couple apart or two friends closer together. My sympathies were definitely with the latter. The couple, who turn out to be rival scientists studying the effects of acid rain on northern flora, are both difficult to tolerate. But things get tragic when the rednecks show up again.

"The River" reminds us that the Garden of Eden is once again the site of The Fall. We as readers crave the innocence of the wilderness but fear its power: survival is more than getting out alive. Next time I hope he uses real place names so I can follow the canoe route at least on a map.

Chuck Erion is the former co-owner of Words Worth Books, Waterloo

(CP) _ Smoke from a massive forest fire in southern Alberta is apparently driving the insects buggy.</p><p nitf:lede="true">An infestation of more than a billion chinch bugs in Medicine Hat on the weekend and a mysterious influx of what appeared to be water beetles in Claresholm last week appear to be related to smoke-obscured skies, says a leading expert on insect migration.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Dan Johnson, a researcher at the University of Lethbridge and the Agriculture Canada Research Station, said insects have been effectively blinded because smoke prevents polarized light from reaching the ground. It's that light insects need to see, to distinguish north from south, and to migrate.</p><p>"About a week ago, I noticed grasshoppers weren't getting up and flying the distances they usually do,'' said Johnson. "They were just hopping along and when you stirred them up, they would just go back into the grass as though they were lost.''</p><p>Johnson recalls one of his teachers, Bill Wellington, advancing the theory that insects use polarized light from the sky _ to them it looks like a map with lines, he said. "They use it to figure out where to go _ we say make a beeline.''</p><p>The use of polarized light for navigation by bees has been studied. However, the same testing has not been applied to grasshoppers, said David Naylor, another University of Lethbridge professor who is an expert in polarized light.</p><p>When light reaches us from the sky, it scatters, said Naylor. The light comes from the sun and strikes molecules in the atmosphere. These are re-radiated and scattered, which polarizes the light.</p><p>The smoke from the wildfire burning in the Crowsnest Pass has essentially cut the polarized light.</p><p>Johnson said chinch bugs usually don't bother anyone and most people don't even know they exist. The tiny bug has a black body, white wings, reddish legs and a black spot on each wing. They like to suck plant juices from many grass species, corn, sorghum and wheat.</p><p>They will have recently sprouted wings and once in the sky without any map to guide them, they focused on light coming from the southeastern Alberta city of Medicine Hat. Johnson said some business lights give off blue or polarized light.</p><p>He offers a similar theory for the appearance of hundreds of water beetles last week in Claresholm, where Joe Shenko, manager of the 7-Eleven store, said it was like walking in a river of bugs in the store parking lot. A few of the critters got inside the store but not enough to warrant closure. Both the hospital and Care Centre also reported hundreds of insects.</p><p>Johnson said he was only able to advance the theory after consulting with Naylor.</p><p>"We have three cases of odd insect behaviour _ grasshoppers, water beetles and chinch bugs,'' said Johnson.</p><p>He is conducting further tests after collecting about 500 live chinch bugs from a McDonald's outlet in Medicine Hat but is convinced the theory is accurate. The insects in that city effectively forced the closure of many businesses, particularly those located in a food court in the Medicine Hat Mall.</p><p>Johnson and Naylor plan to write a scientific paper on their findings.</p><p>"It would be interesting to go back through history and see if, when things like volcanic eruptions and forest fires occurred, whether there were reports of swarmings,'' said Naylor.</p><p>(Lethbridge Herald)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5XGW-9G41-F103-3240-00000-00What you said: New Duncan airport a terrible idea2019-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisNEWSWhat you said: New Duncan airport a terrible ideaSarah Simpson

When Citizen reporter Robert Barron wrote that a study commissioned by the Cowichan Valley Regional District deemed a new airport in Duncan "feasible" members of the community took to social media with their opinions on why it wasn't welcomed.

RELATED STORY: New airport in Valler 'feasible', according to report

RELATED STORY: Air transport in the Cowichan Valley Subject of new study

"What a ridiculous idea! (And I'm someone who flies on a regular basis!)" said Madelaine Shirley.

Leslie Mallett Van Gorkom agreed.

"Madelaine Shirley me too! Honestly do we have to have major noise EVERYWHERE??" she said.

The report recommends that current and future regional planning initiatives undertaken within the CVRD consider the potential benefits of a multi-use regional air transport facility which, along with commercial uses, would also provide essential air services, including air ambulance, search and rescue, emergency evacuation, and forest fire response.

According to a study prepared by Dillon Consulting Ltd., there is sufficient demand for a new airport, but citizens argue there are more pressing transportation issues already on the ground.

"A bridge between Mill Bay and Brentwood Bay is probably the best infrastructure choice that we could make. Faster access to YYJ and a viable alternative to the inevitable problems on the Malahat," wrote Anthony Hull.

"Nanaimo airport is close and Maple Bay has float planes," wrote Jamie MacDougall. "We [need] a bypass for the highway around town more than a new airport."

That comment got more likes than any other post on the page.

"More noise? No! Invest in what is desperately 'needed' such as a vehicle bypass through Duncan?" wrote Jo Nelson.

"Let's get the train first and use it to get to Nanaimo Airport," wrote John Appleby.

"Why don't you concentrate on a better road to get through Duncan first! I think that would be money better spent," wrote Susan Margetts.

"How about a corrections style rehab facility instead of an airport or 30 million dollar concrete cop shop," offered Russell Bissett.

urn:contentItem:5W5Y-KTP1-JBVR-324J-00000-00Wildfires sweep across Israel as heatwave grips region2019-05-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONALWildfires sweep across Israel as heatwave grips regionWildfires sweep across Israel as heatwave grips regionThe Associated Press

JERUSALEM - Wildfires raged in Israel on Thursday amid a major heatwave, with police ordering the evacuation of several communities in the country's centre and south.

Firefighters battled brushfires along the Gaza boundary, as well as near the country's main international airport and outside Jerusalem. A major Tel Aviv-Jerusalem highway was also closed to traffic because of the fire.

Israel and the region are gripped by a major heatwave, with temperatures around the country reaching 100 F (38 C) and higher.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu instructed the Foreign Ministry and Public Security Ministry to seek firefighting aircraft from abroad to help battle the blazes, a spokesman for the premier's office said.

An Israeli police official told Hebrew media that a fire had almost completely destroyed the village of Mevo Modi'im - a community founded by the late songwriting Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach.

Residents of the nearby town of Gimzo evacuated Torah scrolls from the community synagogue as the flames approached.

While police said emergency services were still working to bring the fires under control and had no immediate indication of their cause, the fires broke out a day after Israelis marked the minor Jewish festival of Lag Ba'Omer with bonfires.

A Netanyahu spokesman blamed "incendiary balloons launched by Hamas" for fires near the Gaza Strip in southern Israel, although this was not immediately verified by emergency services.

Gaza militants had floated at least 10 incendiary balloons into Israel on Wednesday, and in response, Israeli authoritiesreduced Gaza's fishing zone from 15 nautical miles to 10.

A massive forest fire in 2010 burned for four days on northern Israel's Mount Carmel, claiming 44 lives and destroying around 12,000 acres, much of it woodland.

urn:contentItem:5RDB-HWC1-JDH3-G4TH-00000-00Upper Clearwater fire crew gets help from credit union2018-01-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisNEWSUpper Clearwater fire crew gets help from credit unionKeith McNeill

By Keith McNeill

A volunteer forest fire suppression crew that began in Upper Clearwater during last summer's wildfire continues to develop.

READ MORE: Upper Clearwater forms its own fire crew (Sept. 26, 2017)

Last week Interior Savings Credit Union donated $3,000 to help the crew.

"Its a pleasure to give this to you guys," said ISCU Clearwater branch manager Gina Walchuk.

The money will be used to help buy a Waterax Mark 3 pump. Commonly known as the Wajax, the pump is a standard workhorse for forest fire crews across North America. Cost for a new one is about $5,400.

"We need to be proactive in Upper Clearwater," said crew boss Steve Murray. "We're 4 ½ hours from Kamloops. By the time they arrive, whatever's happening has happened."

Murray appeared to be referring to the recent consolidation of the Clearwater Fire Zone with Kamloops and the decrease in the staff at the local Forest Service and Wildfire Management Branch offices.

READ MORE: Fire zone boundary redrawn (Sept. 10, 2017)

He gave as an example a small fire that started last year near the power-line into the Upper Clearwater. He and two other members of the crew had it under control before official crews arrived.

Upper Clearwater is outside the zone covered by Clearwater Fire Department and so has no structural fire protection.

"We won't be doing any structural fire suppression, just trying to keep wildfires away from people's homes," Murray said.

The objective will be to hit small wildfires before they become big. If things get out of hand, they will back off.

"We know our limitations," said Murray.

The crew presently has 22 trained members plus another eight in training, he reported.

Murray is qualified to teach 14 of the 17 province's wilderness firefighting courses.

With the experience of last year's wildfire season in B.C., plus the ongoing extended season in California, much of the curriculum has been re-written, he said.

Some of the new video training is interactive so people can learn such things as the most strategic ways to lay out hose-lines.

Next step in the training will be to burn some slash piles in Upper Clearwater. During last summer's wildfire season, many residents cut back branches and trees to FireSmart their properties. Now that debris needs to be burned.

The volunteer fire crew is negotiating with Thompson-Nicola Regional District and Carol Schaffer, TNRD director for Area A (Wells Gray Country) to obtain a used pumper truck.

Such firetrucks can only be in service for a certain number of years before they are retired. Often they have only a few kilometers of use on them and would be usable for an unofficial crew such as in Upper Clearwater.

urn:contentItem:5VD2-BMV1-F103-34KM-00000-00What's going on here: Henvey Inlet Wind2019-02-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisCOMMUNITYPg. 1What's going on here: Henvey Inlet Wind

Construction on the 300-megawatt wind farm on Henvey Inlet First Nation continues after last summer's forest fire, Parry Sound 33, that tore through the site and north into French River Provincial Park.

Just the Facts

- The project is a partnership between Henvey Inlet First Nation and Pattern Energy formed in 2014.

- Construction on the site began in 2017 and, as of last month, 86 of 87 turbine foundations were in place with 34 of 87 turbines installed. The final turbines are expected to be in place this spring with the wind farm completed land restores this summer.

- From Henvey, the power generated will travel along a 104-kilometre transmission line to tap into the provincial power grid, connecting to the system in Seguin Township.

- The transmission line is strung along 1,120 wooden poles that are up to 61 metres tall and 78 steel poles that are up to 49 metres tall. PowerTel is building the line with construction expected to wrap up this spring.

- Once done, it's expected the wind farm will generate the equivalent energy of powering 100,000 homes a year and create over 20 on site jobs, plus more than 100 indirect jobs at Henvey Inlet First Nation.

- Once up and running First Nation and townships that the transmission line passes through - Magnetawan First Nation, Shawanaga, McDougall, Seguin, Carling and Archipelago - are expected to receive funds annually, in additional to more than $10 million in revenue to Henvey Inlet.

urn:contentItem:7WD4-F2M1-2R6R-5149-00000-00Search continues for Ont. pilot who crashed while fighting B.C. forest fire2009-08-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisGENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWSSearch continues for Ont. pilot who crashed while fighting B.C. forest fireCP

LYTTON, B.C. _ An Ontario helicopter pilot who was helping to fight one of British Columbia's many forest fires was still missing Saturday, a day after he disappeared during a dramatic rescue attempt on the rushing waters of the Fraser River.

Robert Christopher Woodhead, 53, of Stoney Creek, Ont., was operating a Bell 212 with a water bucket Friday afternoon when the aircraft when down in the Fraser River near Lytton.

Woodhead, who police said was based in British Columbia, was last seen in the water just after the crash by another pilot who watched from the air as the helicopter went down, said RCMP Cpl. Dan Moskaluk.

''A valiant attempt was made by lowering his line and bucket into the river near Mr. Woodhead,'' Moskaluk said in an interview Saturday.

''However, he was not successful in getting the line to him and did eventually lose visual sight of the pilot in the water.''

Woodhead's family in Stoney Creek said they weren't commenting on the crash.

Moskaluk said police were still considering the search and rescue operation, and were concentrating their efforts on the riverbanks in what is considered a particularly rough part of the Fraser Canyon.

He said several boats were in the water and an RCMP helicopter was searching from the air, but a strong current prevented divers from entering the river.

The helicopter was submerged in 15 metres of rushing water.

The Transportation Safety Board, which has launched in investigation into the crash, believes the helicopter was on approach to pick up water when it went down, said agency spokesman Bill Yearwood.

Yearwood said TSB investigators won't arrive until Monday, and in the meantime will figure out how to remove the helicopter from the water.

''The aircraft is not easily accessible, so there's nothing for us to go look at at this point,'' said Yearwood.

Yearwood said the aircraft was operated by Springbank, Alta.-based Elbow River Helicopters, and was contracted at the time to the British Columbia Forest Service.

Lytton's mayor, Jessoa Lightfoot, said the crash happened in an especially rugged area of the canyon.

''It's very narrow and we have some really severe winds that come through, there's not many roads and it's difficult to reach,'' she said.

The 12-square-kilometre Intlpam fire near Lytton was first discovered July 25, and is believed to have been caused by lightening.

Lightfoot said people living in her community have been fortunate during this year's fire season, avoiding the large-scale evacuations from the same fire that kept thousands from their homes in Lillooet, about 60 kilometres north of Lytton.

But she said residents are no strangers to the threat of destructive forest fires, and they're grateful for the work of the hundreds of personnel who've been working to control the blaze.

''The helicopters - everyone thinks they're a godsend to come and save the surrounding area,'' she said.

''Unfortunately, this seems to be an outcome of man-on-nature, one-on-one. I think there's still hope that he may be found.''

Trevor Mitchell, a pilot with B.C.-based Arrow Helicopters who has spent the past month fighting fires near Revelstoke, said Woodhead would have been working with a ground crew, who would be co-ordinating his water drops.

Mitchell said flying a helicopter with a water bucket is much the same as operating one of the aircraft without one, but the bucket on the end of a line adds to the difficulty.

''It doesn't seem like much, 180 gallons of water, but it's 1,800 pounds,'' said Mitchell.

''It's not the hardest work we do, but it does have a bit of skill required.''

Mitchell said unlike water bombing, which covers large areas at a time, helicopter water bucketing is a more focused procedure.

''You're placing water strategically where they need it,'' he said.

''Whereas a tanker comes in and blankets an area, we come in and thread the needle.''

Friday's crash was the second this fire season.

A single-engine amphibious water bomber cartwheeled into Okanagan Lake on July 25 after the pilot inadvertently left his landing wheels down. He escaped without injury.

A helicopter pilot and two pilots of a four-engine water bomber died in two crashes during the record 2003 B.C. forest fire season.

_ By James Keller in Vancouver

urn:contentItem:5X9H-VYX1-JDH1-C4SY-00000-00Keep B.C. beautiful: letter2019-10-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:53ZLexisNexisOPINIONKeep B.C. beautiful: letter

To the editor and the federal and provincial governments:

Why can't the people of beautiful B.C. stop the pipelines for good? We have not had anyone ask us if we wanted to buy them and we have not had anyone tell us who has been trained (as in a crew) to clean up an oil spill or a (bitumen) an invented word for toxic waste (like the lakes around the tar sands) that the Albertans want shipped to China?

Who will clean up a spill in a forest fire and how hot can a pipe get before it blows up and kills and destroys everything and all life around it?

Also who in the world has trained a crew to clean up beautiful B.C.'s harbours or the open international ocean between us and China when there is an oil or (Bitumen) toxic waste spill?

Oh and who will be responsible for cleaning up the spill? Would it be China for the multitude (300 more) new oil tankers coming our harbours to get it? Would it be Alberta for supplying it? The federal government who bought the pipelines? Or the taxpayers who are already paying for it?

Whose fault will it be? The rich Chinese? The rich Albertans? Or the rich federal government?

Where will be able to find them after they get their tax breaks? Their richest man just died and where did his $500 billion go? Maybe to Trudeau and friends? Or Scheer and friends and family?

It sure won't go to climate change. It's too bad there isn't a children's government. They would do a much better job of running Canada and keeping B.C. beautiful. And by the way, the money we could save on the pipelines could go to restoring and saving the forestry and trucking industries in beautiful B.C. And by the way where does all the recycling go?

It all needs to be recycled with respect to our world. It should all go back to the makers of it. P.S. Please keep beautiful B.C. clean, recycled and green.

Gaye Agnew

Vernon
